title.narrative: Sustainable livelihoods for 1,500 smallholder farming households (7,500 people) in the extreme north of Bangladesh

description.narrative: 1) 1,500 smallholder farming households are working collectively and collaboratively to increase their resilience. Related impact: 60 farmer groups are negotiating with local government and local tea companies/factories for better services and support; and 90% target households perceive benefits from group membership. 2) 1,500 smallholder farming households improve their agricultural practices and start cultivating tea in order to increase their income and reduce their vulnerability. Related impact: Average 3,901 yield of tea (before processing) per acre by the end of the project (rising to an average 6,174 kg yield per acre after 5 years); and 42% of target household income earned from tea cultivation. 3) 1,500 smallholder farming households have appropriate ongoing services/support for agricultural cultivation. Related impact: 1,500 households assisted with agricultural services; 3,000 acres (tea and non-tea) benefiting from agricultural improvements (fertilisers, irrigation etc.); and 90% target households are satisfied with the services/support provided by barefoot service providers. 4) Systems in place to support smallholder farming households to diversify their income. Related impact: 80% of target households have adopted a new income-generating activity (in addition to tea); 4,320,000 BDT of savings mobilised from target households; and group savings and investment schemes are set up to invest in new income-generating activities.

Communities in the extreme north of Bangladesh are isolated with few livelihood options. The sandy acidic soil is problematic for many crops but perfect for tea cultivation. Domestic demand for tea is also growing. Smallholder tea growing therefore provides an opportunity to reduce poverty in these very remote areas. Through provision of tea saplings and technical training, encouraging farmers to work together and ensuring a critical support network, the project will directly benefit 7,500 people.

The project will support 1,500 households (working with 1 man and 1 women from each household) to improve agricultural practices, cultivate tea and adopt new income-generating activities to diversify their income. This will benefit a total of 7,500 people based on a family size of 5.
